title: Hiding the persona sign in until we have features that take advantage of...
body: ... it, per issue #500

title: Design some ways to increase the channel count.
body:
I suspect that fairly often users will run out of channels when making somewhat complex apps.

I'll create some mockups of a channel system that provides more channel options.

title: Start down the lonely path of `ceci-designer.js`

milestone.title: Skeletons in the Closet
milestone.description: Making sure we let the skeletons out of the closet to ensure we build the ramp to contribution out of good bones.

body:
This is where ceci-specific, non-deployable code lives. It is the replacement for `ceci-ui.js`.

It:
* exposes things to *a* designer app that shouldn't be in deployed runtime 
* can add additional functionality to `<ceci-*` tags

milestone.title: Skeletons in the Closet

body:
This should look a lot like the `<div class="card"` elements we currently create, but instead have `<content>` tags with the appropriate selectors.

Additional functions should include:
* `show()`

title: Hammer out <ceci-app>

milestone.title: Skeletons in the Closet
milestone.description: Making sure we let the skeletons out of the closet to ensure we build the ramp to contribution out of good bones.

body:
Should have the concept of a GUID as `id`

Things that currently exist in ceci-app.js like `addComponent` and `addCard` should likely go away. current DOM manipulation functions should suffice unless we need to set up event listeners.


Needs: 
* `cardCount()`

title: Spec out navigation

milestone.title: Skeletons in the Closet
milestone.description: Making sure we let the skeletons out of the closet to ensure we build the ramp to contribution out of good bones.

body:
There are at least three bits IMO:

* make it easy for people to do inter-card component-initiated navigation (e.g. clicking on an item in a list moves to the card showing the details)
* make "going back" obvious
* make it easy to make an app with various pages with maybe only static content that the user of the app can easily navigate between (e.g. nav menu).

title: Hide non-working view/edit source UI
body:
to avoid misleading users.

(we could have a read-only view source, but that's not working yet either)

title: Tags take 2
Figure out a way to test HTML/CSS/JavaScript split/merge
body:
There is certainly a difference in opinion as to which is preferred between "everything in one file" v.s. separate files for HTML/CSS/JavaScript.

We need to decide which is best for newbies. How do we user test it? Might be related to #85

title: The list of components is intimidating and hard to use.

milestone.title: Skeletons in the Closet
milestone.description: Making sure we let the skeletons out of the closet to ensure we build the ramp to contribution out of good bones.

body:
3rd party plugins, menu items and programming idioms are all thrown together in a big list, and it makes it pretty hard to find what I'm looking for (especially if I don't know the right nomenclature).

I'd like there to be usable categories at least, so I don't have to read through the whole list to find the component I need.

Secretrobotron mentioned the goal would be to have a separate gallery like view that's searchable, which is nice, but categories might help in the short term.

title: Should be able to change the size of elements
body: If I make a text input box, I can't resize it. I'd like to be able to have a corner (with a visual cue), which will allow me to drag to resize the box.

title: Discuss using JSLint in components
Hoodification
body:
Heya, this is a larger discussion issue that might lead to more specific issues on various projects down the road.

## Preamble

This goal of this issues is A to agree on a plan forward and B figure all out the technical and social bits that are missing. Well start by writing up a draft plan for A that then informs B. In addition the plan is just a draft, a suggestion and is very much up to discussion and we should make sure we all agree on A before we start working on any concrete items in B.

## A: The Plan

The general idea is integrating Appmaker/designer with Hoodie in the following way:

 1. Make Appmaker/designer a Hoodie application in order to provide a per-user experience of app creation and maintenance.
   - An app author signs up with Persona and gets a customised instance of /designer.
     - In order to allow for loading custom components, this all could live under `username.appmaker.mozilla.org` (or wherever, the username as subdomain is crucial here).
   - An app author can leave /designer and come back later and sign in with Persona to get the state of their apps as they were when they left.

  2. Have Appmaker/designer publish apps as before, but also spin up a Hoodie instance per production app that the users of the app can sign into and that the author of the app has admin access to (Hoodieception).

  3. Figure out what is missing to allow /designer to run offline on tablets. This mostly involves loading components and such.

## B: ToDos

1.a Persona support for Hoodie (https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie-server/issues/169)
1.b Make Appmaker a Hoodie app in that a list of apps and their respective state are stored as user-data that is loaded on signIn.

2.a Have a hosting infrastructure that allows launching and running new instances of Hoodie quickly and reliably. (https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie-server/issues/170).
2.b Have an answer for where the CouchDB for the Hoodie instance lives.
2.c A Hoodie plugin that does the app deployment to S3 and the launching of new fresh Hoodie instances.

3.a Offlinify Appmaker & components selector

title: Unable to sign in

milestone.title: Skeletons in the Closet
milestone.description: Making sure we let the skeletons out of the closet to ensure we build the ramp to contribution out of good bones.

body:
I'm unable to sign in at https://appmaker.mozillalabs.com/# nor http://appmaker.mozillalabs.com/#

I see a request to `http://appmaker.mozillalabs.com/persona/verify` which has the response:
```
{
  "status": "failure",
  "reason": "audience mismatch: port mismatch"
}
```

I took apart the assertion that is sent and in both cases it looks good. The audience is set to 
```
"aud":"https://appmaker.mozillalabs.com"
"aud":"http://appmaker.mozillalabs.com"
```

I'm guessing that the backend app is sending an audience with a port number in it, instead of using what Apache or Nginx exposes to the end user. This is in the call to Persona's verify web service.

title: Timer component interferes with drag and drop snap back
body: When a timer has been added to an app, any other component added to the app and dragged beyond the edge of the screen will permanently change the position of the app frame (it doesn't snap back to centered position).

title: Add calls to action for contribution in the app itself
body:
At this stage of the project, many of the people playing with appmaker aren't target users but likely to be educators and coders, and it's not obvious how they can get involved.

I propose that we add somewhere on the /designer page two links:

  teacher?
  coder?

and have the second be a link to github, and the first be a link to a site aimed at educators.  I'll spin up a separate github repo to design that, and publish as teaching-appmaker.mozillalabs.com

In the meantime, we should link to a wiki page on this github repo.

body:
https://github.com/mozilla/appmaker-components/pull/88/files fixes a problem whereby attributes don't affect the button to which they're affixed.

This workaround may be necessary for all components with the lack of CeciUI's attribute observer. Maybe it should be a part of Ceci core, with some callbacks.
